input_prompt:
Extract all factual claims from this YouTube transcript:

[Music] when McDonald's launched the Big Mac in 1967 it cost just 45 but the same Big Mac now cost $3.99 why the answer is inflation to see how fast prices are rising everything from the price of a leg wax to the cost of a bottle of whiskey are closely monitored by statistical bureaus these changes in prices are entered into a calculator and out comes one single percentage number the rate of inflation and this number helps government set welfare payments and helps you decide how much to ask your boss for a pay rise in a stable economy prices usually go up steadily over time by 1 or 2% a year but sometimes things get out of hand in 2008 prices in Zimbabwe doubled every 24 hours the government printed more and more money before long everyone was a trillionaire things got so bad that the country ran out of paper to print all the bank notes once an inflationary spiral like this begins it's almost impossible to get out of and governments must either devalue their currency or ditch it all together this is what happened in Germany in the 1920s so is inflation bad not so fast a small amount of inflation is usually seen as a good thing it helps keep an economy growing and it also staves off the threat of deflation and a bit of inflation is good news if you're in debt just ask anyone who took out a mortgage on a low interest rate before a property boom but it's bad news for Savers just as inflation eats into debt it also eats into savings 00 stashed in your piggy bank will buy you less in 5 years time than it will today if your income isn't keeping up with prices you're getting poorer for one of the most important Concepts in economics it's also one of the simplest inflation is just the average rate that prices are rising

claims.text: The Big Mac cost 45 cents in 1967 and now costs $3.99.
claims.context: Comparison of Big Mac prices over time, illustrating inflation.

claims.text: In a stable economy, prices usually go up by 1 or 2% a year.
claims.context: General statement about inflation rates in stable economies.

claims.text: In 2008, prices in Zimbabwe doubled every 24 hours due to inflation.
claims.context: Historical example of extreme inflation in Zimbabwe.

claims.text: The government printed more money in Zimbabwe, leading to hyperinflation.
claims.context: Explanation of the cause of hyperinflation in Zimbabwe.

claims.text: Inflation is the average rate at which prices are rising.
claims.context: Definition of inflation as a key economic concept.

input_prompt:
Claim:
Inflation is the average rate at which prices are rising.

Article Title:
Inflation: Prices on the Rise - International Monetary Fund

Full Page Content:
Inflation measures how much more expensive a set of goods and services has become over a certain period, usually a year.

Provide relevant evidence.

output.summary: The evidence confirms that inflation is a measure of how much more expensive a set of goods and services has become over a certain period, which aligns with the claim that inflation is the average rate at which prices are rising.
output.key_quote: Inflation measures how much more expensive a set of goods and services has become over a certain period, usually a year.

Claim: In 2008, prices in Zimbabwe doubled every 24 hours due to inflation.
Category: historical
Extraction confidence: 0.90

Evidence:
UNCLEAR (6 sources):
  1. [PDF] ANALYSIS OF THE ZIMBABWEAN HYPERINFLATION CRISIS | reliability=high (0.90)
     URL: https://honors.libraries.psu.edu/files/final_submissions/953
     Summary: Cagan defines hyperinflations as “beginning in the month the rise in prices exceeds 50 per cent and ending in the month before the monthly rise in prices drops.
  2. Zimbabwe: Inflation at 6.5 quindecillion novemdecillion percent | reliability=high (0.90)
     URL: https://reliefweb.int/report/zimbabwe/zimbabwe-inflation-65-quindecillion-novemdecillion-percent
     Summary: ... inflation rate at around 6.5 quindecillion novemdecillion percent - 65 followed by 107 zeros. "Prices double every 24.7 hours," he noted.
  3. [PDF] On the Measurement of Zimbabwe's Hyperinflation - Cato Institute | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.cato.org/sites/cato.org/files/serials/files/cato-journal/2009/5/cj29n2-8.pdf
     Summary: Zimbabwe first breached the hyperinflation benchmark in March 2007 (Table 1). After falling below the 50 percent threshold in July, August, and September 2007, ...
  4. Hyper Inflation in Zimbabwe - Economics Help | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.economicshelp.org/blog/390/inflation/hyper-inflation-in-zimbabwe/
     Summary: That is effectively a daily inflation rate of 98.0. Roughly every day, prices would double. It was also a time of real hardship and poverty, ...
  5. Hyperinflation in Zimbabwe - Wikipedia | reliability=medium (0.60)
     URL: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperinflation_in_Zimbabwe
     Summary: In 2008, the inflation rate accelerated dramatically, from a rate in January of over 100,000% to an estimated rate of over 1,000,000% by May, and nearly 250, ...
  6. The Return of Hyperinflation in Zimbabwe - Mises Institute | reliability=medium (0.60)
     URL: https://mises.org/mises-wire/return-hyperinflation-zimbabwe
     Summary: ... hyperinflation, reaching 79,600,000,000 percent as prices doubled approximately every 24.7 hours in November of 2008. Today under new ...

Provide the structured verdict.

output.summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that during 2008, prices in Zimbabwe doubled approximately every 24 hours due to extreme hyperinflation, with specific references to a doubling time of about 24.7 hours noted in both the ReliefWeb report and the Mises Institute article.
